metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: HTML Web Storage API
HTML Web Storage API; better than cookies.
content.html: HTML Web Storage API; better than cookies.

content.text: What is HTML Web Storage?
With web storage, applications can store data locally within the user's browser.
content.html: With web storage, applications can store data locally within the user's browser.

content.text: Before HTML5, application data had to be stored in cookies, included in every server request. Web storage is more secure, and large amounts of data can be stored locally, without affecting website performance.
content.html: Before HTML5, application data had to be stored in cookies, included in every server request. Web storage is more secure, and large amounts of data can be stored locally, without affecting website performance.

content.text: Unlike cookies, the storage limit is far larger (at least 5MB) and information is never transferred to the server.
content.html: Unlike cookies, the storage limit is far larger (at least 5MB) and information is never transferred to the server.

content.text: Web storage is per origin (per domain and protocol). All pages, from one origin, can store and access the same data.
content.html: Web storage is per origin (per domain and protocol). All pages, from one origin, can store and access the same data.

content.text: Web Storage API Objects
Web storage provides two objects for storing data in the browser:
content.html: Web storage provides two objects for storing data in the browser:

content.text: Browser Support
The numbers in the table specify the first browser version that fully supports Web Storage.
content.html: The numbers in the table specify the first browser version that fully supports Web Storage.

content.code_html:
API
localStorage 4.0 8.0 3.5 4.0 11.5
sessionStorage 4.0 8.0 3.5 4.0 11.5

content.text: Test Web Storage API Support
Before using web storage, we can quickly check browser support for localStorage and sessionStorage:
content.html: Before using web storage, we can quickly check browser support for localStorage and sessionStorage:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<script>const x = document.getElementById("result");if (typeof(Storage) 
  !== "undefined") {  x.innerHTML = "Your browser supports Web 
  storage!";} else {  x.innerHTML = "Sorry, no Web storage 
  support!";}</script>

content.code:

storage!";} else {  x.innerHTML = "Sorry, no Web storage
support!";}</script>

content.code_html:
<script>
const x = document.getElementById("result");
if (typeof(Storage) !== "undefined") {
  x.innerHTML = "Your browser supports Web storage!";
} else {
  x.innerHTML = "Sorry, no Web storage support!";
}
</script>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:

  !== "undefined") {  x.innerHTML = "Your browser supports Web 
  storage!";} else {  x.innerHTML = "Sorry, no Web storage 
  support!";}</script>

content.text: The localStorage Object
The localStorage object stores the data with no expiration date. The data will not be lost when the browser is closed, and will be available the next day, week, or year.
content.html: The localStorage object stores the data with no expiration date. The data will not be lost when the browser is closed, and will be available the next day, week, or year.

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<script>const x = document.getElementById("result");if (typeof(Storage) 
  !== "undefined") {  // Store  localStorage.setItem("lastname", 
  "Smith");  localStorage.setItem("bgcolor", "yellow");  // 
  Retrieve  x.innerHTML = localStorage.getItem("lastname");  
  x.style.backgroundColor = localStorage.getItem("bgcolor");} else {  
  x.innerHTML = "Sorry, no Web storage support!";}</script>

content.code:
<script>const x = document.getElementById("result");if (typeof(Storage)
!== "undefined") {  // Store  localStorage.setItem("lastname",
"Smith");  localStorage.setItem("bgcolor", "yellow");  //
Retrieve  x.innerHTML = localStorage.getItem("lastname");
x.style.backgroundColor = localStorage.getItem("bgcolor");} else {
x.innerHTML = "Sorry, no Web storage support!";}</script>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<script>const x = document.getElementById("result");if (typeof(Storage) 
  !== "undefined") {  // Store  localStorage.setItem("lastname", 
 "Smith");  localStorage.setItem("bgcolor", "yellow");  // 
  Retrieve  x.innerHTML = localStorage.getItem("lastname");  
  x.style.backgroundColor = localStorage.getItem("bgcolor");} else {  
  x.innerHTML = "Sorry, no Web storage support!";}</script>

content.code_html:
<script>
const x = document.getElementById("result");

if (typeof(Storage) !== "undefined") {
  // Store
  localStorage.setItem("lastname", "Smith");
  localStorage.setItem("bgcolor", "yellow");
  // Retrieve
  x.innerHTML = localStorage.getItem("lastname");
  x.style.backgroundColor = localStorage.getItem("bgcolor");
} else {
  x.innerHTML = "Sorry, no Web storage support!";
}
</script>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<script>const x = document.getElementById("result");if (typeof(Storage) 
  !== "undefined") {  // Store  localStorage.setItem("lastname", 
  "Smith");  localStorage.setItem("bgcolor", "yellow");  // 
  Retrieve  x.innerHTML = localStorage.getItem("lastname");  
  x.style.backgroundColor = localStorage.getItem("bgcolor");} else {  
  x.innerHTML = "Sorry, no Web storage support!";}</script>

content.text: Example explained:
The syntax for removing the "lastname" localStorage item is as follows:
content.html: The syntax for removing the "lastname" localStorage item is as follows:

content.code_html: localStorage.removeItem("lastname");

content.text: Note: Name/value pairs are always stored as strings. Remember to convert them to another format when needed!
content.html: Note: Name/value pairs are always stored as strings. Remember to convert them to another format when needed!

content.text: Counting Clicks with localStorage
The following example counts the number of times a user has clicked a button. In this code the value string is converted to a number to be able to increase the counter:
content.html: The following example counts the number of times a user has clicked a button. In this code the value string is converted to a number to be able to increase the counter:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<script>function clickCounter() {  const x = 
  document.getElementById("result");  if (typeof(Storage) !== 
  "undefined") {    if (localStorage.clickcount) {      
  localStorage.clickcount = Number(localStorage.clickcount)+1;    
  } else {      localStorage.clickcount = 1;    
  }    x.innerHTML = "You have clicked the button " + 
  localStorage.clickcount + " time(s)!";  } else {    
  x.innerHTML = "Sorry, no Web storage support!";  }}</script>

content.code:

document.getElementById("result");  if (typeof(Storage) !==

localStorage.clickcount = Number(localStorage.clickcount)+1;
} else {      localStorage.clickcount = 1;
}    x.innerHTML = "You have clicked the button " +
localStorage.clickcount + " time(s)!";  } else {
x.innerHTML = "Sorry, no Web storage support!";  }}</script>

content.code_html:
<script>
function clickCounter() {
  const x = document.getElementById("result");
  if (typeof(Storage) !== "undefined") {
    if (localStorage.clickcount) {
      localStorage.clickcount = Number(localStorage.clickcount)+1;
    } else {
      localStorage.clickcount = 1;
    }
    x.innerHTML = "You have clicked the button " + localStorage.clickcount + " time(s)!";
  } else {
    x.innerHTML = "Sorry, no Web storage support!";
  }
}
</script>

content.text: The sessionStorage Object
The sessionStorage object is equal to the localStorage object, except that it stores the data for only one session! The data is deleted when the user closes the specific browser tab.
content.html: The sessionStorage object is equal to the localStorage object, except that it stores the data for only one session! The data is deleted when the user closes the specific browser tab.

content.text: Counting Clicks with sessionStorage
The following example counts the number of times a user has clicked a button, in the current session:
content.html: The following example counts the number of times a user has clicked a button, in the current session:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<script>function clickCounter() {  const x = 
  document.getElementById("result");  if (typeof(Storage) !== 
  "undefined") {    if (sessionStorage.clickcount) {      
  sessionStorage.clickcount = Number(sessionStorage.clickcount)+1;    
  } else {      sessionStorage.clickcount = 1;    
  }    x.innerHTML = "You have clicked the button " + 
  sessionStorage.clickcount + " time(s) in this session!";  } else {    
  x.innerHTML = "Sorry, no Web storage support!";  }}</script>
